meanings.definition: To form a connection or bond between different groups of soldiers.
meanings.sent1: The general wanted to intertroop the soldiers from different battalions for a joint exercise.
meanings.sent2: The captain knew it was important to intertroop the platoons to enhance teamwork.
meanings.sent3: The soldiers joked that the training exercise would intertroop them into one big happy family.
meanings.sent4: The sergeant's leadership skills helped intertroop the troops into a cohesive unit.
meanings.sent5: The team-building activities were designed to intertroop the soldiers and foster camaraderie.

meanings.definition: The act of joining or uniting troops together.
meanings.sent1: The intertroop of the battalions was crucial for the success of the mission.
meanings.sent2: The intertroop of different units led to a stronger and more unified army.
meanings.sent3: The intertroop ceremony was a solemn occasion where troops from all divisions came together.
meanings.sent4: The intertroop of forces created a formidable army ready for any challenge.
meanings.sent5: The intertroop of soldiers showcased the military's ability to work as one cohesive unit.

meanings.definition: The process of integrating troops from various units.
meanings.sent1: The intertroop involved careful planning to ensure seamless integration of troops.
meanings.sent2: The intertroop required coordination between different branches of the military.
meanings.sent3: The intertroop of soldiers from different backgrounds brought diversity to the unit.
meanings.sent4: The intertroop process aimed to create a unified front against the enemy.
meanings.sent5: The intertroop of forces was a strategic move to strengthen the army's capabilities.
